answers.text: discrimination at multiple levels of the government,

qas.question: When government computerised ID cards who were adversely impacted?
When did Egyptian court rule that members of other faiths could obtain ID cards without listing faith?

context: Coptic Christians face <a0_0>discrimination at multiple levels of the government,<a0_0/> ranging from disproportionate representation in government ministries to laws that limit their ability to build or repair churches. Intolerance of Bahá'ís and non-orthodox Muslim sects, such as Sufis, Shi'a and Ahmadis, also remains a problem. When the government moved to computerise identification cards, members of <a1_0>religious minorities<a1_0/>, such as Bahá'ís, could not obtain identification documents. An Egyptian court ruled in early <a2_0>2008<a2_0/> that members of other faiths may obtain identity cards without listing their faiths, and without becoming officially recognised.
